loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy plastic bowls, buckets, plates, trays, spoons, etc. in bulk to add to her current ones

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a widow with 5 children aged 15-25 years living in Hioma, Uganda. She has no dependents and she is the sole bread winner in the family. She lives in a rented house with her children and her family goal is to educate her children and build a family house. 

Juliet is a farmer of maize and groundnuts (peanuts) and she has been doing this for 10 years. She faces a challenge of price fluctuations and hopes to expand her farm to include other produce as well. Juliet needs a loan to buy improved seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to buy seeds & fertilizers.

loans.name: 16096 Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana is 33 years old. She is a very efficient lady and performs her routine tasks very well.
She is also a very talented sewing expert and sews beautiful looking clothes for her community clients.
She is a mother of 2 daughters and a son. Her son is only 2 months old while her daughters are studying by attending a local school.
Her husband is a rickshaw driver and provides transportation services to his passengers.
Rukhsana has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah because her husband’s rickshaw has grown old and its body needs to be changed.
With the loan he will buy a new body for the rickshaw that will allow him to save his business asset and also enable him to drive it more smoothly and earn more profits by providing better quality transport services to his passengers.
He has been operating his business for many years and Rukhsana is confident about his success after the loan investment.

loans.use: to buy a new auto-rickshaw body

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more fufu (ground cassava), pepper, and cassava for her  business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more lesos (traditional rectangular colorful cloth) for resale.

loans.name: Maria Theresa

texts.en:
Selling both food and daily-use products is the primary source of income upon which Maria Theresa and her family rely. She makes only about P3,000 each month from her business. She sells sardines, soap, shampoo, sugar, milk and coffee. She has been operating this business for almost three years. Income generated from the business went to school fees and allowances of her four children. 

She is asking for additional capital of P10,000 to buy soft dinks, canned goods, and noodles to sell in her store. These additional items would help increase sales capacity.

In the future, she aims for a better quality of life for her family, especially financing the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy soft dinks, canned goods, and noodles to sell in her store

loans.name: Sheeman's Group

texts.en:
Sheeman is a widow. She lost her husband a few years ago, leaving her to care for their five children. Now her children have grown older and they do different kinds of work to contribute to the family's finances. Sheeman remains at home and does her household tasks. She is still very active at the age of 57.

She has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for the further expansion of her eldest son’s business of selling betel leaves and cigarettes. With the loan he will buy betel leaves and cigarettes of different brands. This will allow him to sell more and earn better profits. He started his business two years ago. Sheeman is confident that her son will utilize the loan in a good way to earn maximum profits for his business.

Note: In the picture, the woman holding a passbook is Sheeman.

loans.use: to buy betel leaves and cigarettes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy household furniture and food, and invest the rest in a small business.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria, 45, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Braulio, her business partner, and a mother to three children who are all in school. While attending to her children, she has also kept herself busy with her business as her way of helping with the family's daily expenses. 

Gloria owns a variety store. She earns money by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located in her residence. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 350 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more grocery items so she will have more stock. The more items displayed at the store the better, as it helps to attract more customers to buy in her variety store. She believes that she will earn more profit and income once she adds more canned goods and pastries. 

Gloria hopes that her business will continue to help her with her family's needs and expenses. She wants all her children to finish their studies and fulfill their own dreams and aspirations in life. She hopes that she will be able to put up another store. She is active in attending the weekly fellowship* as it helps her learn from the Bible. It strengthens her spiritual life.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: L'emprunteuse est une femme mariée, mère de trois enfants.Elle a fait une formation en teinture et en blanchisserie et offres ces services à domicile aux habitants de sa localité.A l'approche des fêtes, elle est très sollicité surtout pour la teinture.L'activité est très rentable et lui permet de participer fortement à l'entretien de sa famille et de prendre en charge ses propres besoins.Elle sollicite auprés de l'UIMCEC un prêt de 200000f pour acheter des produits de teinture et de blanchissement.Elle ambitionne d'élargir son activité et d'ouvrir une cantine pour exposer ses produits de teinture.
texts.en:
Khady is married and the mother of 3 children. She is trained in the techniques of laundering and dyeing, and works for local customers in their homes. Her skills are much in demand during the festival season, especially her dyeing skills. She earns good money and can both take care of her own needs and contribute heavily to the household expenses.

Khady is requesting a 200 000 franc loan from UIMCEC so that she can buy some dye products and laundry supplies. She would like to expand her business activities and, one day, open a small shop in which she can display her dyed merchandise.

loans.use: to buy dye products and laundry supplies.

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en:
Abubakar is applying for another loan to start a motorbike transportation business. He will use this 65,000 Kes loan to purchase a new motorbike for this business. In the future, Abubakar aspires to continue improving and expanding his businesses. 

Since taking his last Kiva loan, Abubakar has greatly improved his family’s standard of living. He hopes to continue accessing the financial services offered by Yehu and Kiva lenders and thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase a new motorbike for his transportation business.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
This is Alma, 54, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Peregrino, 53, who is self-employed. They have two children. The older child helps her in her business; the younger is in elementary school. Her business is a big help in sustaining the family. 

Alma owns a variety store. She earns money by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Apart from her business, she also maintains a small apartment that is being rented for 2,500 PHP a month. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more grocery items so she can have more stock. She also plans to make her store a little bit bigger. She believes that this will help her to gain income and profit as it will definitely attract more customers to buy in her store. It will help her to save more money for the expenses of her children in school. 

Alma hopes that her business will turn into a grocery someday. She wants to become a successful businesswoman. She hopes that her children will be able to finish their studies and have a good life once they settle down. She is active in attending the weekly fellowship* as the sharing inspires her to be optimistic in her life. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Shameem's Group

texts.en:
Shameem is married and has two sons. Both of them have studied till the 8th grade and they are iron-smiths by profession. Her husband is a fruit seller. He sells a variety of fruit to his clients at cheap rates. The quality of his fruit is very good and he has good sales every day.

Shameem is a housewife: she is still very active at the age of 53 and performs her duties very well. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband who wants to buy fresh fruit. This will help him to further increase his sales and profits.

He has been operating his business for many years. Shameem is very confident that after the loan investment, his business will grow further resulting in a better financial life for Shameem and her family.

loans.use: to buy fresh seasonal fruits for a fruit selling business

loans.name: Adehinatou

texts.fr:
Adéhinatou est une femme  âgé(e) de 40ans. Elle est mariée å un  chauffeur et ont  eu 03 enfants.
Adéhinatou travaille comme revendeuse de bouillie et de beignets depuis 1994. Elle vend à ses clients dans un quartier de la place après achat des ingrédients à Lomé et à Kanté. 
Adéhinatou a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter du sucre, du maîs, du haricot et de l’huile servant à préparer la bouillie et le beignet.
texts.en:
Adéhinatou is a 40-year-old woman. She is married to a driver and they have three children.
Adéhinatou has prepared and sold "bouillie" (a type of porridge) and beignets since 1994. She sells her food to customers in the area after buying her ingredients in Lomé and in Kanté.
Adéhinatou has requested her first loan from WAGES in order to buy sugar, maize, beans, and oil for preparing bouillie and beignets.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize, beans, and oil.

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria, 54, is a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Bienvinido, 55, a security guard, and is the mother of an only child. She enjoys being a mother and a businesswoman. She dreams of sending her child through college. 

Candelaria operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy products from wholesalers, selling them per piece for a little profit. Her products are food items. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantity and variety of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Candelaria dreams of being successful in her business and seeing her child finish her education. She never fails to attend the weekly fellowship* wherein she is inspired to share her weekly life experiences with her co-fellowship members and she learns more about the importance of having quality time with God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of food items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to restock on fabrics, ties and accessories.

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en:
Rashid is a hardworking man living in his own house in Hoima, Uganda. For three years he has had a textile business. His business is steadily growing though he has a challenge of price fluctuations. His personal goal is to build a house and buy a car. He hopes to expand his textile business to new markets as well. Rashid needs the loan to buy clothes for resale. 

He also intends to use the loan for buying textile materials for making school uniforms.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Claris

texts.en:
Claris is a 33-year-old married woman with two school-going children. Her husband, Iddi, is a teacher who contributes to the provision of the family's needs. She owns a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children.

Claris has operated a charcoal selling business for the past three years; her potential clients are the local area's residents. She faces the major challenge of customers not paying their debts on time. She aspires to open a boutique in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase fifteen sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fifteen sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: San Cayetano Group

texts.es:
El Comité “San Cayetano” se encuentra en el décimo tercer ciclo del programa "Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras" de la fundación, tiene 17 integrantes. Todas ellas se unieron con el objetivo de crear mayores beneficios para todas ellas por medio del trabajo en equipo. Son mujeres muy activas que regularmente realizan actividades para recaudar dinero para casos de emergencia. 
Una de las miembros es la señora Gladis, quien se dedica a la venta de alimentos de todo tipo. Comenta que le va muy bien en el negocio, puesto que a sus clientes les encanta los platillos que ella prepara. Ya que desea seguir con el negocio solicita el crédito para la compra de carnes, hortalizas, condimentos y demás, los cuales son indispensables para la elaboración de los alimentos. 
Agradece a la fundación por la oportunidad que esta le da, pues la ayuda es muy importante.
texts.en:
The “San Cayetano” committee is in its 13th cycle in the Fundación’s Enterprising Women’s Committee; it has 17 members.  They all joined together with the goal of creating major benefits for themselves through their team work.  They are very active women who regularly carry out fundraising activities for emergencies.

One of the group members of Gladis who sells all kinds of food.  She comments that she does well in the business because her customers love the dishes she prepares.  Because she wants to stay in business she’s asking for a loan to buy meat, vegetables, condiments and others which are indispensable for her meal preparation.  She thanks the Fundación for the opportunity it gives her because the help is very important.

loans.use: to buy meat, vegetables, condiments and more.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to restock on dresses, shirts and trousers for children.

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina is 47 years old and is a widow who lost her husband a few years ago as a result of his sudden death. After his death, she moved to her brother’s home with her three daughters. She didn’t want to become a burden on her brother which is why she started a business making bakery items.

She works very hard to earn money for her family and also provides full support to her brother financially. She takes orders from different bakery shops in the market and fulfills them by providing them with finished goods like biscuits, cakes, bread, etc.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, because she wants to buy flour, sugar, ghee and other bakery ingredients in bulk quantity. This will allow her to expand her business and increase her sales and profits. She has operated her business for many years and is very confident that this investment will help her to earn more profits and save more for the future marriage of her daughters.

Note: In the photo, the lady holding the Asasah passbook is Robina.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, ghee, etc. in bulk quantity to make bakery items

loans.name: Marlon

texts.en:
Due to financial difficulty, Marlon did not pursue his college education because his parents could not afford to finance his schooling. Despite this, he decided to help his parents in managing their farm lots to earn a living and save for their future. They cultivate their rice field twice a year by planting rice. They endure hardships and difficulties as they want to increase their yields and income.

Marlon aims to increase their production and have a plentiful harvest.  He is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy fertilizers and insecticides for his rice farming business. He believes that this loan will help him to increase his yield and hopes that he will earn a higher income to satisfy their basic necessities and to save for future emergencies.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and insecticides for his rice farming business

loans.name: Evaline

texts.en:
Evaline is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school while one is too young for school. Her husband is a businessperson who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and clothing for her family.

Evaline has operated as a water vendor for the past three years; her potential clients are the local area's residents. She faces the major challenge of competition from other operators. She dreams of starting a vegetable grocery.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase stocks of vegetables like tomatoes and onions to start a new vegetable grocery. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access funds to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of vegetables like tomatoes and onions to start a new vegetable grocery.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new car engine

loans.name: 3 De Junio Group

texts.es:
Este grupo es D. la ciudad D. villa elisa, 22 amigas y vecinas se unieron con el propósito D. ayudarse las unas con las otras por medio del trabajo en conjunto. Ellas quieren un mejor futuro para sus hijos y familiares, es por ellos que se sacrifican el día a día.
La señora Adela es una D. las miembros, ella ive en su casita con sus hijos y su marido y trabajan y se ayudan mutuamente. Ella tiene una despensa en su propia casa, el cual está bien surtido. Comenta que le va muy bien, pues ya tiene una clientela bien definida.
Ella solicita el crédito para para poder agrandar su negocio, ya que su espacio físico le está quedando pequeño y quiere seguir creciendo.
Este comité es un grupo que se formo hace cuatro ciclos atrás que a pesar D. tener pequeños problemas supieron salir siempre adelante. La señora Adela al empezar el grupo fue  la  tesorera del grupo y siempre supo llevar muy bien su cargo y es muy responsable en cuanto a los ahorros D. las integrantes .
texts.en:
This Group is from the city of Villa Elisa.  Twenty two friends and neighbors got together so that they could help one-another by working as a team.  They want a better future for their children and families; they are the reason for their daily sacrifices.

Adela is one of the group’s members and she lives in her little house with her husband and children.  She and her husband support one-another.  She runs a small grocery store from her home and it is well stocked.  She says that things are going well for her and that she has steady customers.

She is asking for this loan so that she can expand her business, now that her physical space is getting to be too small and she wants to continue expanding.

This group was formed four cycles ago and despite a few small problems, they always manage to come out ahead.  Adela was the treasure when the group began and she always completed her duties very well and was very responsible with the members’ savings.

loans.use: to buy supplies to stock her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more bonnie fish, spear rid and pig's feet for her business

loans.name: Nakhida

texts.en:
Nakhida is a 44-year-old woman who has been engaged in milk and dairy product sales for the last 20 years. She is an IDP* (internally displaced person). Nakhida is married and has four children. Milk and yogurt are very popular products among Azerbaijani people and they use it in everyday life. Her son helps her to run the business. Monthly income from her business is 300 AZN. Now she has two milking cows and she would like to purchase two more.

*Internally displaced person (IDP) is someone who is forced to flee his or her home in particular as a result of or in order to avoid the effects of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, violations of human rights or natural or human-made disasters, and who have not crossed an internationally recognized State border thus remaining within his or her country.

loans.use: to purchase two cows

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is a married woman with seven children one of whom attends school while the others are grown up. Her husband who is employed also contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly challenge is food for her family and school fees for her child.

Winnie has operated a charcoal selling business for the past five years; in addition, she runs a business selling cosmetics. Her potential clients are women from the local area. She faces the major challenge of competition from other operators. She aspires to expand her business.

With the Kshs 65,000 loan, she wants to purchase sixteen sacks of charcoal and cosmetics for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access funds to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase sixteen sacks of charcoal and cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié, père de trois enfants dont une fille qui fréquente l'école primaire.Il a assisté pendant quatre ans son grand frère qui tient une grande boutique alimentaire en ville.Ayant maitrisé le métier de commerce, il ouvre dans son quartier sa propre boutique .Il vend surtout des denrées alimentaires et parvient à obtenir des revenus très consistants qui lui permettent de prendre en charge sa famille, de payer la location et d'appuyer se petits frères.Pour renforcer son fonds de commerce, il sollicite auprés de UIMCEC un prêt de 250000f pour acheter du riz, de l'huile, des oignons et des pommes de terre.Son ambition est d'ouvrir une boutique pour un de ses frères qui l'assiste.
texts.en:
Abdoulaye is married and the father of three children, out of which one girl attends elementary school. During four years, he helped his brother who runs a large grocery store in town. Having mastered the profession of merchant, he opened his own shop.

He sells mostly food products, and manages to earn a significant income, which enables him to provide for his family, pay the rent and help his younger brothers.

To bolster his business, he's seeking a loan of XOF 250'000 from Kiva's partner, UIMCEC, in order to buy rice, oil, onions, and potatoes. He ambitions to open a store for one of his brothers who is helping him.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, onions, and potatoes

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en: Tarana is a 32-year-old woman who raises and breeds sheep and sells milk products in the local community. Tarana has 3 years of experience in this field. She breeds sheep for meat and fur and keeps one cow to sell milk and yogurt, which are very popular products in Azerbijan. Tarana's profit per month is 250 AZN. Her husband works as taxi driver, but his salary is too low to cover the needs of the family. Tarana's business is the main financial source of income. She has applied for a loan of 1000 AZN to purchase sheep and a milk cow.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and a milk cow.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with six children, four of whom go to school. She takes care of one additional family member (her father). She lives in a rented house and her family does not have access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

She sells green bananas at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. She works seven days a week. Agnes has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy bunches of green bananas. Her major business challenges are seasonality and the increasing prices of green bananas due to high transportation costs. Her aspirations and goals are to become a wholesaler of bananas at the market and also to start going to the villages of Masaka for bananas.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of green bananas

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with three children, none of whom go to school. She has two additional family members (her grandchildren). She lives in a rented house and the family doesn’t have access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent.

She sells tomatoes at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 20 years. She works seven days a week. Agnes has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more boxes of tomatoes and vegetables. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to become a wholesaler and also to start selling different types of vegetables at the market.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes and vegetables

loans.name: Moiwa Bockarie's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org based in Makeni, is very pleased to present to you this group of teachers from Koidu, a city in Eastern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 9,200,000 SLL in order to meet their immediate financial challenges. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries.

Moiwa is the leader of this group of teachers. Moiwa was born in Panguma. He is 42 years old, married and has four children – one in primary school and three in secondary school. Moiwa has been a teacher for 18 years. He has requested this loan in order to pay his children's school fees, renovate his house and invest the rest in agriculture.

loans.use: to pay his children's school fees, renovate his house and invest in agriculture

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
Koffi est un homme âgé de 26 ans. Il est célibataire et n’a pas d’enfants.
Koffi travaille comme revendeur de produits alimentaires depuis 2009. Il vend à la maison après achat au Grand Marché de Lomé. Sa difficulté principale est la mévente.
Koffi a requis son premier  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des sacs de farine de blé, des bidons d’huile des sacs de riz. 
Dans les prochaines années, Koffi voudrait agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
Koffi is a 26-year-old man. He is unmarried and has no children.
Koffi has worked as a retailer selling food products since 2009. He sells his goods at home after buying them at the Grand Market in Lomé. His main challenge is fighting a slump in sales.
Koffi has requested his first loan from WAGES in order to buy bags of wheat flour, cans of oil, and bags of rice.
In the coming years, Koffi would like to enlarge his business.

loans.use: To buy general food products.

loans.name: Rayito De Sol Group

texts.es:
Rayito D. sol se llama el comité formado por 12 mujeres D. la ciudad D. Mariano Roque alonso. Ellas son todas amigas y vecinas D. esa ciudad, tienen como objetivo primordial, la ayuda mutua, para que D. esa forma puedan salir adelante y mejorar su estilo D. vida.
Maria, una D. las integrantes, se dedica a la costura, en lo cual trabaja desD. hace un tiempo, nos comenta que gracias a su trabajo y a su esfuerzo ha logrado salir adelante y crecer. Tiene ya una clientela bien formada debido a que hace buenos trabajos y es muy conocida en el barrio. Ella se define como una mujer muy trabajadora, luchadora y emprendedora.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra D. telas e hilos, con lo cual pueD. abastecer su negocio y D. paso cumplir con la demanda D. sus clientes.
texts.en:
'Rayito D. Sol' (Little Ray of Sunshine) is the name of this committee of 12 women from the city of Mariano Roque Alonso.  They are all friends and neighbors from the same city whose main goal is to help each other so that they can get ahead and improve their lifestyles.

Maria is one of the group's members.  Her business is sewing and she has been in this business for some time.  She tells us that, thanks to her work and her effort, she has managed to make progress and grow her business.  She has a well-established customer base owing to the fact that she does good work and is very well known in her neighborhood.  She describes herself as a very hard-working, tenacious and entrepreneurial woman.

Maria is requesting a loan to buy fabric and threads so that she can stock her business and satisfy her customer demand.

loans.use: to buy fabric and threads for her sewing workshop

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio Sr. is 53, married and has four adult children. They live in a village planting and harvesting rice and vegetables for sale. His wife has been his partner in managing their rice farming business for almost 30 years and they usually earn a profit of PHP 25,000 in every harvest season. They usually spend their income on their basic necessities and to finance their children's education. 

Due to the high cost of commodities and school fees, Rogelio Sr. aims to increase his yields to satisfy their needs and support the schooling of their youngest child. He is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy rice, fertilizers and insecticides for his rice farming business. He believes that through hard work, he will increase his yields and attain his future goals.

loans.use: to buy rice, fertilizers and insecticides for his rice farming business

loans.name: Rahel

texts.en:
Rahel is a 41-year-old mother of two school-going children. Her husband is a businessman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children.

Rahel has operated as a fishmonger for the past five years; her potential clients are the local area's residents. She faces the major challenge of changes in the demand for her products. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 80,000 loan, she wants to start a shylocking (money lending) business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance because they offer efficient financial services.

loans.use: To start a shylocking (money lending) business.

loans.name: Kokoé

texts.fr:
Kokoé est une femme  âgé(e) de 51 ans. Elle est mariée å un coursier. Elle a 02 enfants.
Kokoé travaille comme revendeuse de miel, savons, des sacs en plastiques depuis 2001. Elle vend seule à ses clients dans sa maison  et achéte au Grand Marché de Lomé.
Kokoé a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des cartons de détergent, du miel et divers.
 Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit aider son mari dans les charges du foyer et assurer un avenir radieux à ses enfants.
texts.en:
Kokoé is a 51-year-old woman and mother of two who is married to a courier. Kokoé has been selling honey, soap, and plastic bags since 2001. She works alone from her own home, selling merchandise purchased at the Grand Market of Lomé. 

Kokoé is seeking a first loan from WAGES to buy boxes of detergent, some honey, and miscellaneous other items. She plans to use the profits to help her husband with the household responsibilities and ensure a bright future for her children.

loans.use: to buy boxes of detergent, honey, and other items for resale.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a married woman with four school-going children. Her husband is a businessman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children. 

Florence has operated a charcoal selling business for the past three years; in addition, she operates a grocery. Her potential clients are her neighbors. She faces the major challenge of competition from other operators. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase ten sacks of charcoal and vegetables like onions and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access funds and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase ten sacks of charcoal and vegetables like onions and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with two children both of whom go to school. She takes care of two additional family members (her sisters). She lives in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

Winfred sells second-hand clothes in a shop on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. She works six days a week. She has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to educate her children up to university level and also to start importing second-hand clothes.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Patience

texts.fr:
Patience est une femme âgé(e) de 46 ans. Elle est mariée å un  employé de bureau avec 02 enfants en charge.
Patience travaille comme revendeuse d’alimentation généraledepuis 2005. Elle vend seule à ses clients à la maison après avoir acheté les produits au Grand Marché de Lomé. 
Patience a requis son troisiéme  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des cartons de divers savons,des bidons d’huile,de la mayonnaise et autres.
Elle veut voir ses enfants réussir c’est pour cela elle sollicite ce prêt pour acheter plus de marchandises.
texts.en:
Patience is a 46-year-old woman who is married to an office worker. They have two dependent children. She has been selling general food items since 2005. She works alone from her home, and buys her merchandise at the Grand Market of Lomé.

Patience is seeking a third loan from WAGES to stock up on merchandise such as boxes of various soaps, jugs of oil, mayonnaise, and more. Her goal is to see her children succeed.

loans.use: to buy general food products for resale

loans.name: Mammadali

texts.en:
Mammadali is a 34-year-old man, who has engaged in farming for the last six years.  He is an Internally Displaced Person.  He is married and has three sons. He grows pomegranates and seasonal vegetables and sells them in the local market.  This is a profitable business, especially his pomegranates, which are popular not only in Azerbijan, but also in Russia. This product is in high demand. 

His monthly income from his business is 200 AZN and this is the only financial income for his family.  He has applied for a loan of 1500 AZN to purchase fertilizers and seeds as well as garden tools and to improve his irrigation system.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds for his farm.

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en:
Kibibi is applying for another loan to expand her existing business. She will use this 25,000 Kes loan to purchase more stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, potatoes and cooking oil for her business. In the future, Kibibi aspires to continue improving her business. 

Since taking her last Kiva loan, Kibibi has greatly improved her family’s standard of living. She hopes to continue accessing the financial services offered by Yehu and Kiva lenders and thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, potatoes and cooking oil.

loans.name: San Ramón Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado San Ramón, está integrado por 12 mujeres muy trabajadoras y luchadoras, cuyo objetivo principal es tener un mayor ingreso para poder ayudar a sus familias. Ellas quieren, por medio del trabajo en conjunto, poder ir creciendo, cada una en sus actividades, pero también en el grupo. Están muy conformes con el programa de mujeres emprendedoras de la fundación Paraguaya.
Un ejemplo de trabajo es la señora Delia, quien desde muy temprano empieza a trabajar preparando los alimentos que vende. Comenta que le va muy bien, puesto que gustan mucho las comidas que hace. Tiene una clientela ya bien formada, lo que se podría decir que constituye ya un ingreso fijo.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de carne, verduras, harina, galleta molida y otros ingredientes esenciales para sus comidas. Ella al igual que sus amigas está muy agradecida por la ayuda de la fundación y de kiva.
texts.en:
The group called “San Ramón” has 12 women members who are very hardworking and tenacious.  They goal is to earn higher income to help their families.  They want through teamwork to grow in each of their activities but also as a group.  They are in agreement with Fundación Paraguaya’s Enterprising Women Program.

One example of work is Delia who starts working preparing the meals she sells very early.  She comments that she does very well because the meals she prepares are well liked.  She has a well-formed regular clientele which means a steady income.

She’s asking for the loan to buy meat, vegetables, flour, ground crackers and other ingredients essential for her meals.  She, like her friends, is very grateful to the Fundación and to Kiva.

loans.use: to buy meat, vegetables, flour, groun crackers and others.

loans.name: Vahid

texts.en: Vahid is a 44-year-old cattle breeder who has sold milk and dairy products for the last 17 years.  He is married and has four children.  Vahid is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) and lives with his family in Bilasuvar IDP Settlement.  His monthly income comes from milk and yoghurt sales and it makes him 150 AZN per month.  He has applied for a loan of 1500 AZN to purchase one milking cow and one bull.  He has a good client history and this will be his second loan from AqroInvest.

loans.use: to purchase one milking cow and one bull.

loans.name: Chripus

texts.en: Chripus is married and blessed with two children. One of them is in school. He has been running a posh mill (also known as posho mill, mechanical mill for maize where grains are ground into flour) for the last five years to support his family. Previously, he was farming. He has employed one person to help him in the business. The major challenge he faces is competition so he has to work hard and be aggressive to retain his customers. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access loans to boost his business. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business. He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy maize.

loans.use: To buy maize for processing into flour.

loans.name: Ellesi

texts.en:
Ellesi lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with two children only one of whom goes to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She lives in her own house and her family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

She sells fried cassava and sweet potatoes on a retail basis. She has been in business for one year and works seven days a week. She also has a motorcycle from which she earns income on a daily basis. 

Ellesi has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of cassava, sweet potatoes and cooking oil. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to build rental houses and also to open another stall selling raw cassava and sweet potatoes.

loans.use: To buy bags of cassava, sweet potatoes and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and utensils for cooking.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is married and blessed with a two-year-old child.  For the last two years he has been selling potatoes to support his family.  In the next five years he wants to expand his business.  Stephen dreams of buying a van for distributing potatoes in his region.  He believes that he will become a successful business-man in the future.  He has requested for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings to open another outlet of his business.

loans.use: to open another outlet of his business.

loans.name: Aydin

texts.en: Aydin is 47, married with five children.  He is an Internally Displaced Person.  His primarily business is sheep breeding and cattle.  He keeps sheep for meat and fur purposes and cattle for the sale of milk and other dairy products.  Meat and milk is his most popular product and Azerbaijani people use them in every day cuisine.  This is the only financial income in Aydin's family and his monthly profit is 230 AZN.  Now he has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase one milking cow and several sheep.  He is a good client of AqroInvest with a good client history.

loans.use: to purchase one milking cow and several sheep.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a responsible housewife who aims to become successful in the future. She is 39 and has only one child. She is engaged in a hog-raising business to help her husband to generate income to satisfy their family's needs. She has been in this business for almost five years and usually earns profits of PHP 8,000 for every two pigs she sells.

She planned to acquire more pigs to raise but she didn't have enough capital, therefore, she is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise. She mentioned that this loan will help her to improve her business and she hopes that she will make her business grow in future.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a hardworking business man, aged 47.  He is married and blessed with two children who are in school.  He has been selling clothes for the last eight years to support his family.  He has employed one person to assist him in the business.  In the next five years he plans to establish a wholesale business.  Julius express gratitude to Faulu Kenya for training him in good customer care.  This has helped him to retain his customers.  He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings to add to his stock of clothes for resale.

loans.use: to add to his stock of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Sérigne Talla

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié qui vit avec sa femme et ses trois enfants.Il tient au marché de sa localité une cantine dans laquelle il vend des habits pour femme et enfants ainsi que des chaussures.Avec son activité, il prend en charge les dépenses alimentaires, sanitaires, d'habillement et de frais de scolarité de sa famille.Afin de renforcer son fonds de commerce, il sollicite un prêt de 200000f de l'UIMCEC pour acheter des chaussures et des robes .Son ambition est d'élargir son commerce.
texts.en:
Sérigne Talla is married and lives with his wife and his three children. He runs a small shop in his village, where he sells women's and children's clothing, as well as shoes.

Thanks to his business, he takes care of the various family expenses (food, health, clothes, tuition). To bolster his working capital, he's seeking a loan of XOF 200'000 from Kiva's partner, UIMCEC, in order to buy shoes and dresses.

He ambitions to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy shoes and dresses for children

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Phalla is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She sells Cambodian noodles. Her husband is a soldier. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Phalla is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. By doing so, she can save on transportation costs. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.name: Enena

texts.en:
Enena is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenge of the high cost of transportation while moving from door to door in her business.

With the Kshs 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bee hives for her business.

loans.name: Sahr Daniel's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org based in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you this group of teachers from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They want a loan of 7,200,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) in order to solve their immediate financial problems. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries. Their school’s bursar is directly responsible for doing the repayment on their behalf. 

Sahr is the leader of this group of teachers. Sahr is 41 years old. He is a native of Njaiama Nimikoro, in Eastern Sierra Leone. He is married and has one child who is attending primary school. Sahr has been in the teaching profession for 21 years now. He has requested this loan in order to buy household equipment and invest the rest in his business.

loans.use: to buy household equipment and invest the rest in his business.

loans.name: Balli

texts.en:
Balli is a 28-year-old entrepreneur who is engaged in the poultry breeding business. She has 4 years of experience in this field. She breeds chicken and turkey. Her monthly income from this business is 200 AZN. She is an IDP* and lives with her husband and three sons in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. Balli is a good client of AqroInvest and this will be her fourth loan. 

*An internally displaced person (IDP) is someone who has been forced to flee his or her home due to armed conflict, violence, human rights violations, or natural or manmade disasters, but who, unlike a refugee, has not crossed an international border (source: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)

loans.use: to buy more chicken and turkeys

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, milk, sugar, tomatoes, and various other grocery items

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a single man, aged 30.  He has been operating a business renting rooms for overnight prayers and meetings to make a living.  Peter has been in this business for the last five years.  He has employed three people to assist him in the business.  In the next five years, he plans to expand his business. His major challenge is a lack of electricity in the rental rooms.  For this reason he has requested for a loan of 50,000 Kenyan Shillings to install electricity.

loans.use: to install electricity in his rental rooms.

loans.name: Baasansuren

texts.en: Mr. Baasansuren, 35, runs a translation bureau in the town of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He lives with his son and wife in the boundary district of Ulaanbaatar. He has been running his business for five years and still has not been able to increase his income significantly.  Due to this he decided to start a new business selling coal for fuel usage in addition to his translation business. According to his plan, after his new business becomes stable, his income will increased notably after he pays back all debts. Initially he needs enough working capital to stablize his new business. The loan he is taking will be used to purchase the a large amount of coal for sale.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of coal for sale.

loans.name: Yanjmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Yanjmaa, 56, runs a grocery store in the ger district. A ger is a traditional nomadic Mongolian tent. She lives with her niece in a ger. Her store opened in the autumn of 2010. Her business has been running successfully and already has some permanent customers. 

Now she needs to make some renovation to her store in order to improve her business in the future. She needs new bulks, commodities and a freezer to keep these commodities.

The loan she is taking will be used to cover the cost of new furniture and a freezer for her grocery store.

loans.use: to cover the cost of new furniture and a freezer for her grocery store.

loans.name: Ariuntuul

texts.en:
Mrs. Ariuntuul, 29, is a taxi driver and has been running her business for a half-year. She lives with her husband in Kherlen, a western boundary town of Mongolia. She and her husband used to have their own livestock, but they sold all of them and bought a car to start the taxi business. It is going on successfully and according to her plan.
 
She and her husband have now decided to start another business, a grocery store downtown, because the earnings from the taxi business isn't a large enough income source for their family. Initially she needs 2,500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) for building working capital, such as food commodities for sale. Therefore the loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchase the food commodities from the market for her new grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase the food commodities from the market for her new grocery store sales.

loans.name: Rehoda

texts.en: Rehoda is 38 years old and lives in Bardnersville. She is married and has two children, ages 6 and 10. They live at home and her husband has been a driver for three years now. Rehoda has been operating a cement dirt port in her community and she has more customers. One problem she faces is the rainy season. She is requesting a loan to purchase cements bags for her business. She plans to give her children business skills and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase cements bags for her business

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en: Pauline is a hardworking business woman, age 24. She is married and blessed with two children, both of whom attend school. Pauline also does dairy farming to supplement her income. She describes her business as busy since her potential customers are local residents and passersby. Pauline has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to add to the stock of clothes for resale. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business.

loans.use: to add clothes stock

loans.name: Nrika

texts.en:
Nrika is a married woman with two children, one of whom attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past five years she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is seasonality. She dreams of establishing a café business in the future.

With the loan for 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat oil, rice and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat oil, rice and beans.

loans.name: Khadim  Rassol

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un jeune qui tient une cantine de vente de pièces détachées automobile.Avant d'ouvrir sa boutique, il a d'abord été apprenti mécanicien.Avec l'aide d'un de ses amis, il s'est lancé dans ce type de commerce qui génère plus de revenus que la réparation des véhicules.Ses bénéfices lui permettent de subvenir à ses besoins et d'appuyer son père dans les dépenses d'entretien de la famille.Afin de renforcer son fonds de commerce, il sollicite un prêt de 250000f pour acheter des pièces détachées diverses.Son ambition est d'élargir sa boutique.
texts.en: This borrower is a young man who has a stall for selling spare parts for automobiles. Before opening his shop, he first was an apprentice mechanic. With the help of a friend, he got started in this type of business that generates more revenues than repairing vehicles. His profits enable him to meet his needs and to support his father in caring for the family. To bolster his business capital, he is requesting a loan of 250,000 francs to buy a variety of spare parts. His ambition is to expand his shop.

loans.use: to buy various replacement parts

loans.name: Byambanaran

texts.en:
Mr. Byambanaran runs an auto repair service. He lives with his two daughters and his wife in Kherlen, a boundary town of Mongolia. He has been in this business for six years. During this period he has gained enough experience to stablize his business in the future. His customers always say that Byambanaran is a skilled repairman. This business has been a main income source for his family for the last several years since his wife has been unemployed.

His service equipment has became too old and some of them have been damaged. Therefore he needs a loan to purchase some better equipment to run his auto repair service.

loans.use: to purchase some better equipment to run his auto repair service.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a widowed woman, age 35, who is blessed with two children, both of whom attend school. For the last 7 years, Ruth has been selling clothes to bring up her family. She also practices dairy farming to increase her income. She has employed one person to assist her to manage the business. Ruth has requested a loan of 70,000 KES to buy skirts, blouses and shoes for resale.

loans.use: to buy skirts, blouses and shoes

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Mr. Batbayar, 46, runs a motorcycle transportation business around his town. He has been running his business since last year; he is retired last year from the Military Force of Mongolia. He lives with one of his daughters and his wife. Most of his children have moved out from their parents' house and always try to support their parents with what they can do. This time they also promised to support him in repaying his loan. 

Lately his motorcycle has became damaged; some of it's parts cannot be repaired. Therefore he is taking a loan to purchase some new spare parts for his motorcycle in order to continue his business successfully.

loans.use: to  purchase the some of new spare parts for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Eddah

texts.en: Eddah is married and blessed with three children. She describes herself as a hardworking business woman. She has been practicing poultry farming to support her family. She also runs a grocery business to supplement her income. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business. Eddah is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES to buy more chickens to raise. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to adopt the culture of saving.

loans.use: to buy chickens

loans.name: Munkhtsetseg

texts.en: Mrs. Munkhtsetseg, 37, is a teacher. She has been teaching for seven years. She lives with her husband and daughters in Kherlen, a boundary town of western Mongolia. Her husband works as a fireman and often has a high workload, but his income is not so good. Munkhtsetseg’s monthly salary also does not meet her family expenses, and as such they always face a lack of money. Due to this she and her husband decided to start a new business, a taxi service, to increase the family's income. Now she needs over 3,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to cover the cost of purchasing a new car to start the taxi business.

loans.use: to cover the cost of purchasing a new car to start a taxi business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy food to feed his family and to pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Erdenetogtokh

texts.en:
Mr. Erdenetogtokh works as a driver of a minivan around the districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been working as a hired driver for 5 years and already has become a skillful driver. He lives with his mother and she works as a janitor. 
Recently, he bought a minivan to start his own transportation business.  His earnings will be increased, according to his plan. The loan he is taking will be used to cover the cost of the minivan.

loans.use: To cover the cost of his purchasing a minivan to run his own transportation business.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

For the past five years, she has operated a grocery selling business, selling at retail to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other grocery operators in the area. 

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase sacks of fruits, vegetables, potatoes and charcoal. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fruits, vegetables, potatoes and charcoal.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She is a farmer, and her husband sells palm products. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Ly is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more cattle to raise for sale. By doing so, she is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cattle to raise for sale.

loans.name: Njolele S.h.g B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Njolele B S.H.G. Group in Western Kenya! Emily is the facilitator of the Njolele B S.H.G. group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Emily takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Emily had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, she was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Emily and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Emily will educate her children, ensure food security for her family, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Njolele B S.H.G. group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

In the picture the person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Sokhai

texts.en:
Sokhai is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She is a farmer, and her husband is a construction worker. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Sokhai is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase pigs to resell. By doing so, she is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy pigs to resell.

loans.name: Sangay

texts.en: Sangay is 32 years old and lives in Barnersville.  She is single and has a 3 year-old child at home and in school.  For the past three years, she has been running a provision shop in her community.   She makes more profits and has more customers since she is the only one who sells tissue, quality soap, oil, and etc.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more tissue, soap , oil, and others items for her business.  Her plan is to develop her shop into a store.

loans.use: to purchase more tissue, soap , oil, and other items for her business

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Sarom is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She is a farmer, and her husband is a construction worker. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Sarom is requesting a loan of USD 500 to pay for her children’s school fees. By doing so, her family members will be able to generate more income when they are graduated. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to pay for the children's school fees.

loans.name: Kimlang

texts.en:
Kimlang is married and resides with her husband  in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She is employed at the factory, and her husband is a construction worker. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Kimlang is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase pigs to resell. By doing so, her family is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to purchase pigs to resell.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past five years, Mercy has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high transportation costs in her business. Mercy's major dream is to establish a large market to meet her customers' needs. 

Mercy plans to use this KES 40,000 loan to pay for hospital bills. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To pay for hospital bills.

loans.name: Neoun

texts.en:
Neoun is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She is a farmer, and her husband raises pigs to resell. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Neoun is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work in the city. By doing so, her family is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.name: Sahr Hilton's Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers of a secondary school in Koidu, a city in Eastern Sierra Leone. This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 4,700,000 SLL in order to meet their immediate financial challenges. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries.

Sahr Hilton is the leader of this group of teachers. A native of Koidu, the 49-year-old is married and has five children – three in primary school and two in secondary school. Sahr has been a professional teacher for 24 years. He has requested this loan in order to invest in agriculture and in a small scale business.

loans.use: to invest in agriculture and in a small scale business

loans.name: Suha

texts.en:
Suha a 29-year-old housewife, who is a mother to a son and daughter. Suha is married to Nael who works full time in one of the Jordanian governmental entities. 

At home after Nael finishes his work, Suha and her husband help each other to create beautiful mosaic paintings and crafts. Nael started this business and taught his wife Suha, it has been nine years since they started working in this field. 

Suha has applied for this loan to buy new tools that are needed to make this art, as the ones they have are old and need to be renewed. 

Because Suha is a conservative person, Nael has agreed to appear in the photo instead.

loans.use: to buy new tools that are needed to make mosaic art

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Phalla is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She is a farmer, and she raises pigs at home. This couple works so hard every day for income to help cover the family expenses. 

Phalla is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more piglets to raise for sale. By doing so, her family is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more pigs to raise for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock

loans.name: Miyekwe Care Group

texts.en:
Joseph is the facilitator of Miyekwe Care group. Joseph and his group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Joseph and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Joseph had an excellent maize yield harvesting 15 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Joseph was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With the income from maize sales, Joseph will invest in buying a cow and then build a house. 

In 2012, the members of Miyekwe Care group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ghada

texts.en: Ghada started a small retail business 10 years ago selling blankets, clothes and towels. Because Ghada is a conservative person, her son Mohammad has agreed to be in the photo instead. Ghada is a 43-year-old housewife. She has six sons and daughters. She buys her products from either Aqaba or Ramtha, where she can find the products cheap; then sells them after adding some profit in Marka, her home city. Now Ghada has applied for this loan to buy items in larger quantities to add to her collection.

loans.use: to buy more clothes items in larger quantities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food

loans.name: Sevda

texts.en: Sevda is 59 years old and is engaged in farming.  She has grown seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last twenty years.  Sevda is married and has one daughter.  Her husband works in construction as a labourer and his salary is about 100 AZN, which is not enough even to cover basic family needs.  Sevda  sells her products in her shop which is located in the central Agsu market.  Her monthly profit from this business is 220 AZN.  She has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers and to purchase more items for her shop.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Bidii A Group

texts.en:
Kevin takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to grow enough to feed his family, to ensure food security for his family and later to educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Kevin had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 ½ bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, he was only able to harvest 2 ½ bags of maize on ½ an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Kevin will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

Kevin is the facilitator of the Bidii A Group. In the photograph above, Kevin is pictured with his group members. Kevin and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Bidii A Group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Kevin and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food products to sell in his business.

loans.name: Ñepytyvo Group

texts.es:
Con el sueño de mejorar su estilo de vida, 10 mujeres de la ciudad de Caaguazú se unieron, ya que vieron en el programa de la fundación paraguaya una gran oportunidad. Ellas son muy conocidas en el barrio por su trabajo en conjunto y por la ayuda que se brindan las unas a las otras.
una de las miembros es la señora Ana, quien gracias a la despensa que tiene logra salir adelante y ayudar a su familia. Comenta que tiene muchos clientes, ya que la mayoría de sus vecinos se acercan hasta su negocio para comprar. Uno de sus sueños es seguir creciendo y volverse una gran comerciante.
Ella solicita el crédito para abastecer su negocio con bebidas, comestibles, panificados, lácteos y demás, con lo cual podrá cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes. Agradece a la fundación por la oportunidad que esta les da.
texts.en:
With the dream of improving their lifestyles, 10 women from the city of Caaguazú came together as a group because they saw a great opportunity in Fundación Paraguaya's program.  They are very well known in their neighborhood for their joint work and for the help that they give each other. 

One of the members of the group is Ana who, thanks to the grocery store that she runs, has been able to get ahead in life and help her family.  She tells us that she has a lot of customers as most of her neighbors come to her business to do their shopping.  One of her dreams is to continue growing her business and become an important shopkeeper.

Ana is requesting this loan to stock her business with drinks, food, baked goods, dairy products, etc.  This will enable her to satisfy her customers' demands.  She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the opportunity that they are giving her.

loans.use: to buy drinks, food, baked goods, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Chikaze B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Chikaze B Group in Western Kenya! With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jotham and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Jotham is the facilitator for this group. He is in the photograph with his group members. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Chikaze B group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Jotham takes care of six children at home with his wife. He joined One Acre Fund in order to boost his maize production and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Jotham had a very good maize yield harvesting 13 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jotham was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Jotham will pay for major expenses such as school fees.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Khadidiatou

texts.fr:
Khadidiatou est une femme habite dans la région du sude au sénégal,agée de 35 ans veuve.Elle fait le commerce depuis l'age de 18 ans.Elle a 9 enfants 5 enfants dans une école de l'agence des musulmans d'afrique(AMA),2 enfants sont à l'école primaire etles 2 plus petits restent avec elle à la maison.
khadidiatou avec ce crédit elle augmente son fonds de commerce,pour mieu satisfaire ses clients.Elle est,a son 3eme crédit sans aucun retard de remboursement.khadidiatou,achete des chaussures en guinee pour les revendre au sénégal, avec ce commerce,elle assure ses dépenses quotidienne et les frais de scolarisation des enfants.
Khadidiatou dans l'avenir avec les bénéfices,elle veut construire son terrain qui est dans la ville.
texts.en:
Khadidiatou is a 35-year-old widow who lives in southern Senegal. She has 9 children, 5 of whom attend the AMA (African Muslim Agency) school and 2 of whom are in primary school. The youngest 2 stay at home with her.

Khadidiatou has been a saleswoman since the age of 18. She buys shoes in Guinea so that she can resell them to her clientele in Senegal. Her income allows her to cover the household expenses and pay for her children´s education.

Khadidiatou is requesting a loan to invest in and increase her business, so that she is able to meet customer demand. This is her third loan request and she has fully repaid her previous loans. One day, she would like to use the profits from her business to develop the property she has in town.

loans.use: to buy shoes and fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase two milking cows

loans.name: Baraka C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Baraka C Group in Western Kenya!

In the recent 2011 season, Peter had a good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Peter was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on one acre of land. Peter takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. With income from maize sales, Peter will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

Peter is the facilitator of Baraka C group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.  Like the majority of people in this part of Kenya, the members of Baraka C Group are farmers who rely on maize for yearly food security and income. In 2012, the members of Baraka C group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Peter and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Precious

texts.en: Precious is 28 years old and lives in Bardnersville. She is single and has a child that attends school and lives at home. For the past three years, Precious has been running a grocery shop where she sells many items such as toothpaste, cream, nutrition, etc. She has a lot of customers and her daily sales are very high during the dry season. Precious is requesting a loan to purchase more inventory for her business. Precious plans to expand her business and wishes her children to continue the business.

loans.use: to purchase more toothpaste, cream, and other items

loans.name: Raila

texts.en: Raila is a 51-year-old woman, who has been engaged in milk sales for the last four years.  Rakhila is married and has five children.  She has two milking cows and sells milk and homemade yoghurt to the local people.  Raila's profit in this business is 150 AZN per month.  This is the only financial income in her family and Raila is aiming to expand it.  To do that she has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase one milking cow and fodder.

loans.use: to purchase one milking cow and fodder.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more items.

loans.name: Valentine Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Valentine Group in Western Kenya! Eunice takes care of nine children at home. In the recent 2011 season, Eunice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Eunice was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on one acre of land. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to feed her family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. With income from maize sales, Eunice will educate her children and invest in business.

Eunice is the facilitator of the Valentine Group. She is pictured with her group members in the photograph.This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. Like the majority of people in this part of Kenya, the members of Valentine Group are farmers who rely on maize production for annual food security and income. In 2012, the members of Valentine Group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Eunice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more merchandise.

loans.name: Ancille

texts.en:
Ancille is 23-years-old and is married. Her business is clean and good. She sells shoes. Ancille has three years experience in this business and employs one person to help her. Her business is open from 7am until 8pm every day.

Ancille has requested a loan from Kiva via vision finance company in order to purchase more elder and children shoes for resale. With any profit from the loan, Ancille will expand her business, reinvest and save for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more elder and children shoes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more beer and soft drinks

loans.name: Norma Fidelina

texts.es:
